explanation: Section 300 defines murder; Section 302 provides punishment. 302 cannot be charged without establishing ingredients under 300
Section 378 defines theft; Section 379 is the punishment provision always charged alongside 378 as they are inseparable
Section 499 defines defamation; Section 500 provides punishment. Cannot charge 500 without proving 499 ingredients
Section 503 defines criminal intimidation; Section 506 provides punishment. Always charged together in intimidation cases
Section 191 defines giving false evidence; Section 193 provides punishment. 193 applies to both 191 and 192
Section 463 defines forgery; Section 465 provides basic punishment always charged with definition sections
Section 141 defines unlawful assembly; Section 147 is punishment for rioting which requires unlawful assembly
Section 146 defines rioting; Section 147 provides punishment always charged with rioting cases
Both sections deal with cheating; 417 is minor cheating without property delivery; 420 is aggravated cheating with property delivery
Section 501 complements 499 specifically covering printing of defamatory matter; more specific than general 499
Section 502 complements 499 specifically covering sale of printed defamatory matter; extends liability to sellers
Section 466 is a specific form of forgery targeting court records; more specific than general forgery under 463
Section 467 is aggravated forgery of valuable security or will; higher punishment than basic forgery under 465
Section 468 is forgery specifically for purpose of cheating; combined with cheating provisions
Section 470 defines a forged document; definitional section that supports other forgery charging sections
Section 471 punishes using forged document knowing it to be forged; complements making of forged document
Section 379A is snatching which is a specific form of theft with sudden force; more specific than basic theft
Section 379B is enhanced punishment for snatching when hurt is caused; supplements basic snatching under 379A
Section 304A covers death by negligence which is not intentional and falls outside murder definition in 300
Section 307 covers attempt to murder when death does not result; complement to completed murder under 302
Section 304B covers dowry death which is a specific presumptive form of culpable homicide; complements murder provisions
Section 354A specifically covers sexual harassment forms of assault on women; more specific than general 354
Section 354D covers stalking specifically; complement to general outraging modesty provisions
Section 326B covers attempt acid attack; complements completed acid attack causing grievous hurt under 326A
Section 146 defines rioting using force; complement to 141 which defines unlawful assembly prerequisite
Section 148 covers rioting with deadly weapons; more aggravated form complementing basic rioting provisions
Section 149 makes every member of unlawful assembly liable for acts done in common object; complements 141
Section 364A covers aggravated kidnapping for ransom; complements general kidnapping under 363
Section 192 covers fabricating false evidence while 191 covers giving false evidence; together cover all false evidence scenarios
Section 197 covers false certificates; specific complement to general false evidence provisions under 191
Section 198 covers using false certificate; complements issuing false certificate under 197
Section 171A defines candidates and electoral right; prerequisite definitional section for all election offences
Section 171A definitions apply to undue influence under 171C; prerequisite definitional linkage
Section 171A definitions underpin personation at elections under 171D
Section 171B defines bribery; Section 171E provides punishment; always charged together
Section 171C defines undue influence; Section 171F provides punishment for undue influence and personation
Section 290 provides punishment for public nuisance in cases not covered elsewhere; supplements 268
Section 272 covers adulteration of food; Section 273 covers sale of noxious food; together address food safety violations
Section 274 covers adulteration of drugs; Section 275 covers sale of adulterated drugs; together cover drug adulteration
Section 489B covers using counterfeit currency; complements making of counterfeit currency under 489A
Section 489C covers possession of counterfeit currency; supplements making offence under 489A
Section 489D covers tools for counterfeiting; complements all counterfeiting offences under 489A onwards
Section 489E covers documents resembling currency; complements core counterfeiting provisions
Both sections address marriage fraud; 493 covers deceitful cohabitation; 494 covers bigamy; often co-occurring
Section 495 is aggravated bigamy where former marriage is concealed; supplements basic bigamy under 494
Section 496 covers fraudulent marriage ceremonies; complements actual bigamy offence under 494
Section 304B covers dowry death as outcome of persistent cruelty covered under 498A; natural progression
Section 306 abetment of suicide complements cruelty provisions when persistent 498A cruelty drives victim to suicide
Section 425 defines mischief; Section 426 provides basic punishment always charged with definition
Section 427 is aggravated mischief causing Rs 50 damage; more serious than basic mischief under 426
Section 435 covers mischief by fire; most serious form of mischief complementing basic provisions
Section 436 covers mischief destroying house by fire; most aggravated specific form of mischief
Section 396 is dacoity with murder; most aggravated form complementing basic dacoity under 395
Section 414 covers assisting concealment of stolen property; complements receiving stolen property under 411
Section 341 defines wrongful restraint; Section 342 defines wrongful confinement which is more serious; degrees of same wrong
Section 305 is abetment of suicide of child or insane person; complements homicidal offences under 300
Section 313 is causing miscarriage without woman consent; aggravated form complementing 312
Both deal with provocative and threatening communications; 504 is insulting; 506 is threatening; often co-charged
Section 507 supplements 506 by adding punishment for anonymous intimidation; same base offence with anonymity aggravating factor
Section 509 covers insulting modesty through words or gestures; lesser form complementing physical assault under 354
Section 497 adultery was struck down by SC in 2018; conflicts with 494 bigamy in matrimonial law landscape; 497 no longer applicable
Section 307 attempt to murder is charged when act done with murder intent but death does not result; mirrors 302 in intent
Cheating under 417/420 and criminal breach of trust under 406 both address dishonest property taking; often confused but distinct
Section 409 is aggravated criminal breach of trust by public servants or bankers; complements basic 406
Both involve falsification; forgery under 463 covers documents while 489A covers currency counterfeiting; same fraudulent intent
Section 294 obscene acts in public is specific form of public nuisance covered generally under 268; more specific provision
Section 295 covers physical desecration of religious places; 295A covers intentional insult through acts; two aspects of religious offences
Section 296 disturbing religious assembly is specific religious offence complementing 295 desecration
Section 297 trespass on burial places complements 295 covering religious and sacred spaces
Section 298 covers wounding religious feelings through utterances; milder complement to 295A malicious acts
Section 310 defines Thug; Section 311 provides punishment; definitional-punishment pair inseparable
Both sections address organized criminal groups; unlawful assembly under 141 is broader; thug under 310 is specific criminal gang
Section 395 dacoity is aggravated robbery by five or more persons; complements simple theft under 379 at higher scale
Section 498 covers enticing away a married woman; Section 498A covers cruelty; distinct but both in matrimonial context
Section 171G covers false election statements; Section 171H covers illegal payments; related election offences often co-occurring
Section 466 forgery of court records directly complements false evidence provisions under 191; both target judicial process integrity
